<s>it consists in a circulating or a vibrating motion of the Rays 
or of the medium, or something else, I do not presume to 
explain; those who are averse from assenting to any new dis-
coveries, but such as they can explain by an Hypothesis, 
may suppose that those rays which when passing out of 
glass into Air, & would continue to move on in streight 
lines if uninterrupted; when they arrive within the 
influence of a second refracting stratum, receive a new 
impulse in a direction different from that of the first, 
& those contrary impulses may be repeated many times 
while the rays are under the influence of both strata; & 
those <u>repeated vibrations<\u> may affect the rays according to their 
different degrees of refrangibility, in such a manner as to 
seperate them into several coloured spectra. And as it has 
been showen in the 13th experiment, that coloured rays in 
passing each other are mutually affected therby; it is therfore 
highly probable, that b this compound action & reaction, 
both between the refracting strata & light, & between the rays 
of light themselves, the various phenomena are produced, 
altho' from the extream minuteness of all the operations of 
light, a perfect knowledge of the mode of those operations, 
is more to be wished for than expected.<\s> However "as every Desideratum may be considered as an important discovery" 
which when compleated may lead to others of still greater im-
portance; & as the subject is so far from being exausted that 
perhaps we are only entering on a new career of 
discoveries, not only in opticks but in every other 
branch of natural knowledge; in this point of view, 
the prospect before us is rendered extensive as 
it is animating & delightful.
John Know
Belfast Octr 6 1812.
